discussion.content: Answer ADE, I read it from my Admin 2 textbook.
I think answer BDE. Answer A could is to strict; The charactersets must be compatible. Doc: https://docs.oracle.com/database/121/ADMIN/transport.htm

comments.content: B is not correct because we can convert endian

discussion.content: I think the correct answer is ABE

choices.D: The minimum compatibility level for both the source and target databases must be 10.0.0.
choices.E: The tablespace to be transported must be in read-only mode.
choices.A: Both the source and target databases must use the same character set.
choices.C: The compatible parameter value must be the same in the source and target databases.
choices.B: The platforms of both the source and target databases must have the same endian format.

questions.question_text: Which three requirements must be met before a tablespace can be transported across different platforms?

discussion.content: I agree, it should be A
I would choose answer A because clustered tables are not recommended for oltp.

questions.question_text:
In a database supporting an OLTP workload, tables are frequently updated on both key and non-keycolumns.
Reports are also generated by joining multiple tables.
Which table organization or type would provide the best performance for this hybrid workload?

choices.A: heap table with a primary key index
All the read-only tablespaces should be taken offline.
choices.D: All the read-only tablespaces should be made online with logging disabled.
choices.C: All the read-only tablespaces should be renamed to have the MISSING nnnn format.
choices.B: All the read-only tablespaces should be restored separately.

comments.content:
Yes its A. we both used the same site
https://web.stanford.edu/dept/itss/docs/oracle/10gR2/backup.102/b14191/recoscen006.htm

questions.question_text:
In your database, there are tablespaces that were read-only when the last backup was taken. These tablespaces have not been made read/write since then. You want to perform an incomplete recovery on the database by using a backup control file.
What precaution must you take for the read-only tablespaces before performing an incomplete recovery?

discussion.content:
Couldnt believe it. the answers here were wrong.
YES C D
Answer should be C and D.

choices.E: It creates a backup of only the control file whenever the database undergoes a structural change.
choices.B: It creates compressed backup sets by using binary compression by default.
choices.D: It backs up data files, the control file, and the server parameter file.
choices.C: It backs up only the used blocks in data files.

questions.question_text: Which statement is true about the loss or damage of a temp file that belongs to the temporary tablespace of a pluggable database (PDB)?

choices.B: The PDB is closed and requires media recovery at the PDB level.
choices.D: The PDB does not close and starts by using the default temporary tablespace defined for the CD.
choices.C: The PDB does not close and the temp file is re-created automatically whenever the container database (CDB) is opened.
choices.A: The PDB is closed and the temp file is re-created automatically when the PDB is opened.

discussion.content:
I agree on C answer.

The PDB can open with a missing temporary file. If any of the temporary files do not exist when the PDB is opened, they are automatically re-created. They are also automatically recreated at CDB startup.
